title: Dražan Jerković
text:
Dražan Jerković (; 6 August 1936 – 9 December 2008) was a Yugoslav and Croatian professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a> and <a href="Football%20player">player</a>. His professional playing career spanned from 1954 to 1966, during which he played for <a href="GNK%20Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo Zagreb</a> and <a href="K.A.A.%20Gent">AA La Gantoise</a>.
Biography.
His first name is sometimes (incorrectly) spelled "Dražen". He was born in <a href="%C5%A0ibenik">Šibenik</a>, at the time in the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Yugoslavia">Kingdom of Yugoslavia</a>.
Playing career.
Jerković played for <a href="GNK%20Dinamo%20Zagreb">Dinamo Zagreb</a> (1954–65). Severe injuries forced him to retire early, at the height of his career. With Dinamo he won the league title in 1958, and league cup in 1960 and 1965. In 315 games for Dinamo, he scored 300 goals.
He played internationally for <a href="Yugoslavia%20national%20football%20team">Yugoslavia</a> between 1960 and 1964, scoring 11 goals in 21 games. He participated in the <a href="1960%20European%20Football%20Championship">1960 European Championship</a> and the <a href="1962%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1962 FIFA World Cup</a>. He was also part of the Yugoslav squad for the <a href="1958%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1958 FIFA World Cup</a>, but did not play.
In UEFA Euro 1960, he scored two goals against <a href="France%20national%20football%20team">France</a> in the semifinal, which Yugoslavia won (5–4). In the final, Yugoslavia lost against <a href="USSR%20national%20football%20team">USSR</a> (1–2; AET), finishing second.
In the 1962 FIFA World Cup, Jerković scored four goals and was, with five other players, the top goalscorer, winning the <a href="World%20Cup%20Golden%20Boot">World Cup Golden Boot</a>. Yugoslavia finished in fourth place. In the quarter-final, Yugoslavia beat <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">Germany</a>, while in the semifinal they lost to <a href="Czechoslovakia%20national%20football%20team">Czechoslovakia</a> (1–3) and lost to <a href="Chile%20national%20football%20team">Chile</a> in the third place match (0–1).
Jerković played in a single international match with Croatia, as the <a href="Croatia%20national%20football%20team">Croatia national team</a> was assembled in communist Yugoslavia once for a <a href="Croatia%20v%20Indonesia%20%281956%29">friendly</a> against <a href="Indonesia%20national%20football%20team">Indonesia</a> in 1956. He was also the first manager of the Croatia national team since independence, between 1990 and 1992.
He died on 6 December 2008 in <a href="Zagreb">Zagreb</a>.
